meanings.definition: The forward edge of a fore-and-aft sail that is turned into the wind.
meanings.sent1: The sailor adjusted the luff of the sail to catch the wind.
meanings.sent2: The luff of the sail fluttered gently in the breeze.
meanings.sent3: The mischievous seagull perched on the luff of the sail, enjoying the view.
meanings.sent4: The luff of the sail reached out like a welcoming hand to the wind.
meanings.sent5: The bright red luff of the sail stood out against the blue sky.

meanings.definition: To steer a sailing vessel closer to the wind.
meanings.sent1: The captain decided to luff up to catch the wind from a better angle.
meanings.sent2: The sailor had to luff to avoid a collision with another boat.
meanings.sent3: The crew cheered as the ship began to luff gracefully towards the horizon.
meanings.sent4: The yacht seemed to luff effortlessly through the choppy waters.
meanings.sent5: The experienced sailor knew exactly when to luff for maximum speed.

meanings.definition: To flap or curl, as a sail in the wind.
meanings.sent1: The sail started to luff loudly in the strong gusts of wind.
meanings.sent2: The old sailboat's canvas began to luff noisily in the storm.
meanings.sent3: The sail continued to luff comically, making the crew burst into laughter.
meanings.sent4: The sail luffed like a giant bird trying to take flight.
meanings.sent5: The luffing sail added a sense of adventure to the peaceful voyage.
